title: Do you think science and technology breakthroughs always represent progress? - Quora

response.answer_text: Technology is a tool; it can either be used for good or ill. Discovering how to split atoms to cause a nuclear chain reaction can either be used to provide energy to entire cities, or it can be used to blow them up. Silicon Valley is the single most powerfully innovative culture in the history of the world. The technologies produced there have disrupted entire industries, almost overnight. But the technology can be used either for good or evil. People use Facebook to report to their loved ones that they are safe during a hurricane. Other people use it to stalk their exes, or to spread fake information to sway elections. The problem is that disruption is regarded as inherently positive, when in reality there are unforeseen consequences of using these technologies that aren't. The germ theory of disease has enabled scientists to develop cures and vaccines that have demonstrably improved the lives of millions of people. However, part of the reason WWI was such a horrible conflict is the use of biological and chemical agents to kill the enemy. I think the main takeaway is that the ethics of using technology does not always keep pace with the technology itself.

Yes, absolutely, by definition. To answer this question, I think it’s instructive to look at a couple of definitions of “progress” (mine are from Google Define): forward or onward movement towards a destination.development towards an improved or more advanced condition.Now, in light of this: Science strives to learn more and more about the world. A scientific breakthrough is exactly a movement toward this destination, a more advanced state of knowledge. Technology is about applying knowledge to find solutions to problems, to advance toward goals. Certainly, better technology gives people better means to achieve their goals. Better mousetraps and all that. Again, this is the definition of progress! I suspect the question really means to ask if progress is always an advancement in the right direction, for whatever you may want to define “right” as: Greater happiness and less suffering for humanity, more money in Jeff Bezos’ bank account or global domination. The answer to that question would depend on whether you presuppose that most people and their goals are good or evil.

Always. To know something newhas never been less than a good thing. If I understand your question correctly then perhaps you’re conflating knowledge or advances in technology as having not benefited mankind. Perhaps, though you’re confusing understanding or knowledge with its application or the combined problems of politics/human behaviour/misapplication of that knowledge. That’s a seperate thing entirely. You can’t cherry pic knowledge. You have to accept that some things you’re going to like and some things you’re not. Some things help. Some things don’t. You don’t know what won’t help unless you understand what it actually is you’re looking at.

Not always. Sure, as we grow into a new era of technology, lives become easier to live. But I believe that because we have it easy, it takes away a part of us. Our empathy seems to degrade, and other societies who can't afford the same technological advances are left in the dust. It's cool to move forward, but we leave many things behind: including people.

Huxley said it all in one sentence thirty years ago. Believing in progress is believing in getting something for nothing. French writer Jean Giono tells how his father said the same thing, more or less, but in quite different words. As a ten-year-old he ran to his father, a shoemaker, and said, 'Look, father, in the newspaper, there's a plane now that goes three hundred kilometres an hour.’' 'So what?’ replied his father. 'When they get off the plane, they still can't talk to each other.'

Yes, absolutely. An increase in knowledge is always beneficial. Ignorance is dangerous. What is done with that knowledge is another matter entirely. Science provides us will ability. Technology has produced microwave ovens and atomic bombs.

Depends on perception, if you believe they are working towards the most efficient future I would say so. If it's a technological breakthrough on let's say a combustion engine I'd say no, They could have focused their time on non combustable engine production. But upgrading anytging progresses it further.

Almost never!! Quick example: small tribes in any third world region lack nothing. Technology only increases dependency on electricity and stimulates laziness.. what is known as efficient, is really the demise of able bodied people.
No. But it does seem (to me) that things found in maths, around 100 ~ 200 years ago, find application now. Eg Finite element analysis.
